case_title: MUHAMMAD BAKHSH and others vs Mst. JAINDAI and others
complaint_summary: The case revolves around the legality of several mutations concerning land transactions between vendors and vendees, and whether these transactions violated provisions of M.L.R. 115 regarding partial inalienability of holdings.
investigation_summary: The Revenue Officer, Assistant Commissioner/Collector, and Additional Commissioner reviewed multiple mutations. Some mutations were upheld, while others were remanded for reconsideration based on M.L.R. 115 provisions.
judgment_summary: The court declared provisions of para. 24 of M.L.R. 115 as un-Islamic with retrospective effect. All revision petitions were accepted, and mutations were directed to be sanctioned to give effect to the sales.
Decision_or_verdict: Revision accepted; provisions of M.L.R. 115 declared un-Islamic with retrospective effect.
legal_arguments: Provisions of M.L.R. 115 were violative of Islamic principles.
Vendors cannot challenge transactions they willingly entered into.
The doctrine of estoppel applies as the law was declared un-Islamic ab initio.

maxims.Estoppel: Vendors are estopped from challenging transactions under an un-Islamic law.

legal_terms.Mutation: A change in ownership or title of land.
legal_terms.Inalienability: Restriction on the transfer or sale of property.

words_and_phrases.Economic holdings: Minimum size of land holdings required for economic viability.

summary_vector_notes: The judgment addresses the retrospective invalidation of M.L.R. 115 provisions as un-Islamic, emphasizing the responsibility of vendors in ensuring compliance with the law and the application of Islamic principles to past transactions.
